If I'm not mistaken this comment is saying that a mission of the EPA - to set limits on discharge of contaminants into the environment - is unconstitutional. Limits set for GHGs to protect the health of US citizens and the natural environment from the effects of climate change is really no different than setting MCLs (maximum contaminant levels) for such constituents as benzene and arsenic for the NPDES (national pollutant discharge elimination systems) for surface water.

Essentially MCLs are based on empirical and analytic observation and mathematical models, respectively. The science to calculate MCLs is pretty much accepted, but with our evolving understanding of biochemistry and genetics, MCLs may come up for argument. We saw this with arsenic MCL in the 2000s.

Now GHG limits will be established scientifically in the same light as MCLs for water. Acceptable levels will be argued back and forth between the government scientist and its consultants and industry and its consultants. And eventually levels will be set.

On a legal level the EPA as an entity would have to be unconstitutional - not its practice of setting discharge levels - since it has been doing that for over 40 years without constitutional challenges. Ron Paul, Rick Perry and others would be proud I guess. So much for clean air, water and land.

I agree, and one very good reason to override EPA is the fact that in all other cases of regulation involving the use of computer models, the models are subject to Verification and Validation (V&V). All this (upsurge in "unconventional oil" production) hardly disproves the theory of Peak Oil. This theory postulates that the cheap oil (measured in Energy Return on Energy Investment) days are over. (It does not postulate that oil "runs out," whatever that means.) This is still true. More oil can be produced, but at ever greater environmental cost. The high cost of oil can now be "externalized" in the form of environmental disaster: extensive soil and water pollution, global warming, etc. But the cost is till there, and it will eventually have to be paid, no doubt in the form of eventual population decline (as the planet becomes unlivable for humans).

I agree with your overall view, but large homes are being sought after by multi-generational family groups, often from countries where this is the norm.

I think starter homes will be in demand and eventually in short supply as foreclosure inventories are consumed and new construction remains depressed. But at the opposite end, high priced homes will take a longer time to recover.

Before 2007, many of the high end buyers were those of average means who moved up by leveraging accumulated equity of their own and family that has since been wiped out.

And the idea of the home as an investment has lost favor, especially as a sole investment.

Then there is the Baby Boom demographic, which means less new household formation.

In short, I do not expect a return to the halcyon days of booming construction and home prices.

Your comment seems very mixed up.

You are incorrect. Not every pollutant regulated by EPA Clean Air Act rules is tied to a specific air quality standard.

The regulation of emissions of air pollutants from stationary sources is addressed though the Clean Air Air requirement that such sources install the best available control technology. While not as effective in achieving emision reductions as other means might be, this approach is the result of the specific directive Congress has given to the "unelected ideologues" to whom you refer. So far the regulation of greenhouse gas emissions from stationary sources has done little to affect such sources or any impact they may have on "modern life".

On the other hand, the substantial reduction of tailpipe emissions of GHGs from light trucks and cars in the U.S. will certainly make a significant dent in solving the GHG emissions problem.

How do these rules actually solve the carbon dioxide problem? Every other EPA rules sets a standard of the offending material in the air or water and sets a concentration limit. In what way do these rules address the concentration of CO2 in the air? How can a regulation possibly pass any test of rationality if the regulation is not calculated to and cannot possibly solve the purported problem?

This isn't about protecting the environment. This is about social policy via the guise of environmental protection. This is you deciding what aspects you hate about modern life and using an agency of unelected ideologues to destroy those aspects. This is lawlessness wearing a black robe.

House is increasingly affordable housing prices "negative"?

If you think we're even remotely close to the price bottom, you're going to be stunned over the coming years and decades.

I am encouraged by all the negative comments. This to me is a good sign that the bottom has been reached. Times of maximum pessimism are often good entry points into markets. As in March 2009 when the S&P was below 700 or long term treasuries yielding 15% in the in the early 1980s.

There will never be an all clear signal that it is safe to buy. There will always be some sort of crisis somewhere. People need to focus on fundamentals such as price/rent and prince/income levels. These ratios, particularly combined with mortgage rates below 4%, are highly suggestive that housing is a good deal right now.

In past financial crises home prices bottomed out on average six years after the prior peak (Japan being the very big exception to this rule). So if history is any guide we should be bottoming right now.

I think that the government will be better off spending on the other programs like health care, education, energy etc. rather than increasing the military spending since there will be a higher chance of creating better and decent paying jobs when compared to defense program. It is true that it is important to maintain a decent defense budget but it should be based on realistic assessment. Also, increasing military spending, may end up pulling out resources from various other productive programs which will overall not benefit the economy.

One of the things driving the development of new sources of oil in North America is the relatively high price of oil, meaning that a price collapse is not likely to happen -- or would be short-lived if it did. This means that innovation in fuel economy is likely to continue.

For its part, the development of new natural gas sources is undeniably having a net positive impact on the climate and the environment generally. Say what you will about fracking -- I believe that it can be done responsibly, but it needs better regulatory oversight -- from extraction to emissions, natural gas is cleaner than coal in almost every respect. The construction of new coal capacity in this country is now at a virtual stillstand, and fracking is the biggest reason why.
